bestBHT.bht: In the analogy given, Jesus likens His coming to that of a thief, underscoring the unexpected nature of His arrival and the necessity of constant watchfulness. The servants mentioned in the analogy symbolize those entrusted with the Lord's house and household collectively. Loins girded signifies being prepared and ready for action. The comparison to a thief emphasizes the need for unwavering vigilance, as the owner of the house would have been watchful to prevent his house from being broken into if he had known the hour of the thief's arrival.

Henry Alford: Nothing can be more exact and rigid than the connexion as it now stands.

Our Lord transfers, to shew the unexpected nature of his coming, and the necessity of watchfulness, the relation between Himself and the servants, to that between the thief and the master of the house.
For the purposes of this verse, they represent the master of the house—collectively, as put in charge with the Lord’s house and household.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: loins . . . girded—to fasten up the long outer garment, always done before travel and work (2 Kings 4:29; Acts 12:8). The meaning is, Be in readiness.
Marvin Vincent: What hour [ποια ωρα] . See on Matthew 24:42.
Would come. Lit., cometh. See on Matthew 24:43.
Philip Schaff: Luke 12:39. But know this, etc. A new figure (of the thief in the right) brings out the unexpected return. See on Matthew 24:43-44.
Archibald T. Robertson: The Master returning from a wedding is replaced by a thief whose study it is to come to the house he means to plunder at an unexpected time.
Apodosis of second-class condition, determined as unfulfilled, made plain by use of αν with aorist indicative.
He would have watched, though he did not allow.
John Gill: That if the good man of the house had known what hour the thief would come... he would have watched and not have suffered his house to be broken through."
And so in like manner, could it be known in what time Christ would come... every thoughtful, prudent man that should know it, would be upon his guard.
Though the precise time could not be known, yet inasmuch as the thing itself is certain, it became all the servants of Christ to be watching for it.

bhtAttempts.bht: The connection in Luke 12:39 is exact and rigid, as our Lord uses the relation between Himself and servants to describe the unexpected nature of His coming and the necessity of watchfulness. The servants here represent the master of the house, emphasizing the collective responsibility of being in charge. The phrase loins girded signifies being in readiness before travel or work. Just as the thief comes at an unexpected time to plunder, the Master's return from a wedding is unexpected. If the good man of the house had known when the thief would come, he would have watched and not allowed his house to be broken through, which illustrates the need for vigilance.

In Luke 12:39, Jesus compares His coming to that of a thief, emphasizing the unexpected nature of His return and the need for constant watchfulness. The servants mentioned in the verse symbolize those entrusted with the Lord's house and household. In order to be ready, they are instructed to have their loins girded, which was a practice done before travel or work. The image of the thief underscores the importance of remaining vigilant, as the master of the house would have watched if he had known.

The connection in this passage is precise and revealing, as Jesus compares Himself to a thief, highlighting the unexpectedness of His coming and the necessity of watchfulness. The servants mentioned here represent those responsible for the Lord's house and the household. The instruction to have their loins girded implies being prepared. The imagery of a thief emphasizes the need for constant vigilance; had the owner known the hour, he would have watched to prevent his house from being broken through.

The connection in this passage is exact and rigid, as Jesus uses the analogy of a thief to describe the unexpectedness of His coming and the importance of watchfulness. The servants referred to here represent those entrusted with the responsibility of the Lord's house and household. The instruction to have their loins girded signifies the need for readiness. The image of a thief underscores the need for constant vigilance, as the owner would have watched if he had known when the thief would come to prevent his house from being broken into.

In the analogy given, Jesus likens His coming to that of a thief, underscoring the unexpected nature of His arrival and the necessity of constant watchfulness. The servants mentioned in the analogy symbolize those entrusted with the Lord's house and household collectively. Loins girded signifies being prepared and ready for action. The comparison to a thief emphasizes the need for unwavering vigilance, as the owner of the house would have been watchful to prevent his house from being broken into if he had known the hour of the thief's arrival.
